title: Thunderbird 115.5.1 not responding when deleting messages
content:
I don't recall this being an issue before but now with Thunderbird when deleting multiple messages, TB freezes with the "not responding" message. The more messages, the longer the delay.

By using Shift Delete, and bypassing the trash folder it is instantaneous. Other than that, is there any other solution?

Thanks

content:

title: All messages deleted from one of my IMAP email accounts
content:
I'm on version 115.5.1, Windows 10. One of my small pet dogs was in my lap, resting its head near my keyboard. I was in Thunderbird, reading a message, when all of a sudden all of my messages in INBOX were suddenly deleted. I thought maybe exiting Thunderbird might bring them back. BAD IDEA!! Since I have empty Trash Bin on EXIT checked. Unfortunately that worked just fine.

I have a laptop that also is setup with the same IMAP accounts. I disabled the Internet connection on that computer, and the emails are still there as long as I don't connect to the internet. I tried copying all the files in the profile from the laptop to the desktop, but as soon as I launch Thunderbird, it sees that the inbox is empty, and removes (or basically updates) that inbox.

I tried export/import (export msgs from laptop, import to desktop) but maybe I don't fully understand the import process, because that doesn't seem to work for me.

One other option might be to make that account OFFLINE (so it doesn't connect anymore) change the name of that email account, and recreate the account.

I'm open to suggestions - there are 240 msgs in that INBOX that I need to keep for reference. (And I will no longer keep msgs in the INBOX, I'll move them to new folders!!)
creator: skyguy2

title: gmail whacking users for not physically signing in
content:
So gmail is doing what it does best by blocking users who don't routinely sign in on their site. Right now I have lost access to 6 emails I use pretty much daily.

Does TB have any plans on tweeking the program so when someone using TB and has gmail accounts will actually be recognized by gmail as a legit sign-in? One would think gmail's system would treat a sign-in by TB the same as it does physically being on gmails site to sign-in...right? Apparently not.

Also, after the last update, TB is not handling gmail folders very well. I have to wait to see what I deleted, saved, etc..compared to before. It looks like TB is signing into gmail for each and every process instead of the one time per account? Why? This might explain why gmail keeps telling me "You have attempted to sign into your account too many times...please come back later" This is after one attempt to physically sign-in on each of these 6 accounts. Now they blocked sign-ins to all of them thinking I'm a hacker.

I'm not complaining, just trying to understand.

title: Thunderbird 115.5.1 not correctly marking emails as "read" since last major update
content:
Several updates ago, Thunderbird does not seem to be able to correctly mark each message as "read". This issue did not seem to occur with any frequency some months ago (>1%), but since upgrading to the latest versions this error now occurs with a decent percentage of emails (~10%).

Automatic marking of emails as "read" after being viewed for some time does not work on these emails; I can be sitting waiting for several minutes, and these emails are never marked as "read" despite most other emails being correctly marked as they are viewed, typically within seconds.

Manually marking these emails as "read" does not always work either; these messages are quickly reverted back to "unread" status, and it can take several attempts (and a couple minutes) to mark an individual message as "read".

It appears that the latest updates have changed the way these read/unread flags are handled and communicated with the mail server, in a way that is not consistent from one message to the next.

title: 2 Methods for Convert Thunderbird file to Outlook PST file
content:
You must have the Thunderbird client installed on your computer to use the manual method of importing Thunderbird emails into Outlook. Because you cannot import a Thunderbird MBOX file into a Outlook PST file if you do not have any email clients.

These are some easy steps:

  • Launch Thunderbird on your PC.
  • Email addresses to be chosen:
  • Choose the emails you want to export. You can choose multiple emails by holding down the 'Ctrl' key while clicking on each one.
  • Select Save As from the context menu.
  • Right-click on the selected emails, choose "Save As," and save them to your computer.

However, because the manual method is difficult to use and has the risk of data loss. As a result, I suggest the professional tool. Try the ToolsCrunch Mac Thunderbird to PST Converter Tool to convert your data. This tool easily convert Thunderbird emails to Outlook without any data loss. It is works on all Windows OS and Mac versions. This tool converts vast amounts of data from Thunderbird files to PST files. You can try the free test versions and analyze this application.

There are some easy steps:

  • Install the MBOX to PST Converter Tool and run it.
  • Select MBOX file and then "browse"
  • Display an MBOX file mailbox preview
  • Click Browse and enter a location for the save files.
  • Select the Convert button.

title: Disable the request for a specific certificate.
content:
Hello, I have a problem, Thunderbird requests confirmation of a security exception for a certificate at least once a day (we have a PALOALTO firewall at our company and I can't get past it).

And the topic is that in order to send a message or download from the server, you need to confirm a security exception - then the program shouts an error, that the exception cannot be acknowledged, but a repeated attempt to send/download allows it to work and the email is sent/downloaded.

I mean, is it possible to disable the request for a specific certificate? Because all TH users in the company are telling me that it bothers me.
creator: olczakster

title: Thunderbird
content:
Hi, I kept OS Snowleopard around for years too long in order to keep using Eudora. I finally got fed up with viruses/crashes, having to rebuild the mailboxes, but I was never able to find anything to take its place and have frankly been limping along ever since. I regularly need to find things going back months, years, and even decades. It used to be simple with Eudora. Recently, one of my parents passed away and I'm kind of the family scribe, so I really need to pull together all the past communications, from Eudora (going back to almost 1990), gmail, yahoo, my website, icloud, my college alumni address, my Ronin Institute address, my 15 Sonic addresses--and there's probably a few I'm forgetting offhand. I really need to consolidate them. I tried various email clients, including years ago a previous version of Thunderbird, but they were a lot of work to set up and couldn't handle all the email addresses.

I see better reviews of Thunderbird now. Can Thunderbird really handle all those email addresses? Since my Eudora mbox files are still on OS Snowleopard, and I'm running Macbook M1 with the latest OS now, what's the best way to incorporate the entire archive of messages and also start hopefully wrangling current messages (like I haven't been able to since I had to stop using Eudora)? Eudora pretty much only did POP well, and I actually did appreciate having my data on my own computer, but now there are some email accounts I'd prefer as IMAP and others as POP. Is it possible to mix them? Is it possible to download AND keeps messages available for viewing by phone? This situation has been a problem for me for years--I was just wondering if there might be any volunteers at Mozilla who might be willing to spend a few hours on the phone with me to help me bring my email into the 21st century? Nearly every day of my life I have to let someone down over something I can no longer do or find because I don't have Eudora. But the problem doesn't go away just because I find another program that does some of the things Eudora did--I really need some help integrating everything. Thanks so much for all you do!
creator: sundogspot

title: Impedir que usuário altere a senha do servidor
content:
Bom dia,

Existe alguma forma de bloquear a alteração de senha do servidor de envio e recebimento no Thunderbird?

Utilizamos ele em nossa empresa e, quando acontece algum problema com o servidor que gerencia os e-mails, por exemplo uma manutenção, o Thunder tenta contatar para verificar novas mensagens e, quando não consegue, mostra a tela que ocorreu falha de comunicação e pede para fornecer uma senha nova, conforme a imagem em anexo.

O problema é que não divulgamos a senha para os colaboradores, somente a equipe de T.I. detém a mesma, ai acontece que um colaborador esquecido insere uma senha que ele acha ser a correta, como a que ele no computador por exemplo, e quando o serviço de e-mail retorna esse colaborador é o unico a não receber pois gravou uma senha errada.

Alguém conhece uma forma de impedir isso?
creator: kivell

title: Relatório/Recibo de entrega de e-mail
content:
O servidor do meu provedor de e-mail é capaz de me repassar relatórios/recibos de entrega de e-mail, confirmando se houve ou não êxito na entrega do e-mail remetente ao e-mail destinatário. Através do sistema web deste e-mail consigo assinalar essa opção em cada mensagem que envio para decidir se quero ou não este recibo.

Gostaria de usar essa mesma função no Thunderbird, já que a maioria dos e-mails que encaminho é através dele. É possível? Encontrei um tutorial na internet falando que em "Configurações de Conta" haveria essa funcionalidade para configuração, mas a única funcionalidade mais parecida com isso que encontro no Thunderbird é a de "Confirmação de Leitura" (que não é o que eu quero, apenas a confirmação de entrega).

Poderiam me ajudar a esclarecer se é ou não possível configurar relatórios/recibos de entrega a partir do Thunderbird?
creator: Magnopc

title: How to have the current message in the middle of the message list pane?
content:

As a result, I have no way to anticipate what will come next, cannot quickly move to messages in the same thread.

Is there a way to make it so the current message is always in the middle of the message pane instead of being always at the bottom when "n" is used or always at the top when "p" is used, which hides the messages that are next to be displayed in both cases?

In the attached screenshots to illustrate what I want, the good one is where the current message is in the middle. The bad one is where the current message is at the bottom of the message list pane.

title: Unified Inbox broken since updating to V.115
content: I have used Fiefox on my Windows computers for many years, regularly updating. Nothing I saw prior to updating to v.115 a few weeks ago led me to realise that my combined Inbox would be broken apart. I did ask for a "downgrade fix" pretty immediately, but have had no reply. Looking at other users' questions about v.115, I see many people with similar problems after upgrading. I now have to look in all those of my accounts which appear beneath the top Inbox header (which with trouble I found and have made visible), but also in other haphazardly located inboxes further down the mailbox hierarchy or listings, to pick up those messages not appearing with the bulk of the others. The suggested fixes for lack of global inbox were far too technically intricate for me to tackle and all I really want is my old display of emails back. I do appreciate that as a highly technical person, but with no experience of the most consistent mailbox settings, I may have somewhere gone wrong over the years and this could have helped the current confusion. Thunderbird has become a current hardly usable jumble. But until now, there really weren't any problems. Can anyone help me revert to my previous working Thunderbird layout, without my having to re-program the beast? Thanks.
